title: Lesson 1: The Great Commission - You Are Sent
description: The last words of Jesus before the ascension and what they mean for every believer: you are not a supporter of someone else's mission. You are sent.

blocks.text: In 201 you went deep - the gospel, identity, spiritual disciplines, the foundation of the Christian life. In 202 you grew up - the Holy Spirit, Scripture, the church, community, home, hospitality. Now in 203 the direction changes. Everything you have been building turns outward. This course is about living on mission in the world God has placed you in. It starts with the most important words Jesus ever said before he left.
The Last Words of Jesus

When someone is about to leave permanently, their last words carry unusual weight. Jesus knew this. In the final moments before his ascension, he did not give a farewell speech or a closing prayer. He gave a commission - a mandate, an assignment, a direction to move. These words have been shaping the church for two thousand years, and they are addressed to you.

And Jesus came and said to them, "All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, to the end of the age."

Three things anchor this commission. All authority has been given to him - he does not send you out unequipped. All nations - no person, culture, or neighborhood is outside the reach of this mission. I am with you always - the same presence that animated his ministry on earth goes with you. The commission is impossible without those three anchors. With them, it is simply a matter of going.

1.1 - What specifically makes you feel inadequate or unqualified for the Great Commission? Write it honestly. Then look back at Matthew 28:18-20 and identify which of the three anchors speaks directly to that fear.
You Are the Plan
Jesus said to them again, "Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you."

The logic of this verse is exact: how the Father sent the Son is the pattern for how the Son sends you. And how was the Son sent? Into ordinary human life. A neighborhood in Nazareth. A carpenter's shop. Meals with tax collectors. Conversations at wells and in fishing boats. Jesus did not carry out his mission primarily through events or platforms. He carried it out through presence - showing up, noticing people, building trust, and letting the gospel work through everyday relationships. That is the model. You are not supporting someone else's mission from a safe distance. You are sent.
1.2 - When you picture a "missionary," what image comes to mind? How does John 20:21 expand or challenge that picture for your own ordinary life?
Jerusalem First
But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth.

Jesus does not send his disciples to the ends of the earth first. He sends them to Jerusalem - the city where they already are. Then outward in expanding circles. The global scope is real and it matters. But it always starts where you are right now. The most common reason people are ineffective in mission outwardly is that they have never become missionaries inwardly - in their own homes, with their own family, among the people who know them best and see them most.

You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your might. And these words that I command you today shall be on your heart. You shall teach them diligently to your children, and shall talk of them when you sit in your house, and when you walk by the way, and when you lie down, and when you rise.

The oldest model of disciple-making in the Bible is a household saturated with the presence of God - faith woven into the ordinary rhythms of sitting, walking, lying down, rising. Your Jerusalem is your front door. The mission starts there and expands outward from there.
1.3 - Using the Acts 1:8 circles, rate yourself 1-10 in each sphere: Home, Neighborhood, Workplace, World. Where are you most intentional? Where is the biggest gap, and why?
Make Disciples, Not Just Converts

The command in Matthew 28 is not "tell people about Jesus" - though that is included. It is "make disciples" - people who follow Jesus and help others follow Jesus. The difference between addition and multiplication is enormous over time. Telling one person is addition. Investing deeply in one person who invests in another who invests in another is multiplication, and it is the strategy that changed the world in the first century. It is still the strategy.
And what you have heard from me in the presence of many witnesses entrust to faithful men, who will be able to teach others also.
1.4 - What is the difference between telling someone about Jesus and making a disciple? What would that difference look like in one specific relationship you already have?

1.5 - Name one specific person in your home, neighborhood, or workplace that God seems to be putting on your heart. Write their name. What is one step you could take this week to move toward them intentionally?
Closing Reflections
What is one key thing you learned from this lesson?
What is one step you are going to take this week?
What is a prayer request for this week?
